case.summary: Applications by the accused individuals in two separate trials for a determination of whether the "Carter" defence was still available following amendments to the Criminal Code section 258(1) and for an order declaring that the amendments violated their Charter rights. The accused indiivuduals argued that the amendments were HELD: Applications dismissed in part. The amendments were procedural and not substantive because they were evidentiary. Therefore they operated retrospectively. The "Carter" defence was still available. The burden of proof was not changed by the amendments. The amendments did not infringe any of the Charter rights enjoyed by Canadians.
